Can splits.next().unwrap() cause a panic? (Medium)

(Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-coverage/src/coverage_map.rs] [Function: update_coverage_from_trace_file()] [Invalid Address] When AccountAddress::from_hex_literal() is called with .unwrap(), can malformed hex addresses (invalid characters, wrong length) cause panics instead of graceful error handling? [File: third_party/move/tools/move-coverage/src/coverage_map.rs] [Function: update_coverage_from_trace_file()] [Invalid Identifier] When Identifier::new() is called with .unwrap() for func_name and module_name, can attackers provide invalid Move identifiers (with special characters, too long, empty) to cause panics? [File: third_party/move/tools/move-coverage/src/coverage_map.rs] [Function: update_coverage_from_trace_file()] [Unbounded Growth] The BTreeMap structures (exec_maps, module_maps, function_maps) have no size limits - can an attacker craft a trace file with millions of unique entries to exhaust memory? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-coverage/src/coverage_map.rs] [Function: insert()] [Cascade Insertion] The cascading insert operations create nested BTreeMap entries without bounds checking - can this be exploited to create deeply nested structures consuming excessive memory? (Low)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-coverage/src/coverage_map.rs] [Function: to_unified_exec_map()] [Quadruple Nested Loop] The four nested loops iterating over exec_maps, module_maps, function_maps, and pc entries could have O(n^4) complexity - can a specially crafted coverage map cause CPU exhaustion? [File: third_party/move/tools/move-coverage/src/coverage_map.rs] [Function: ModuleCoverageMap::insert_multi()] [Counter Saturation] If coverage counters overflow from u64::MAX back to 0, could this cause incorrect coverage reports that hide actually executed code, affecting security audits? (Low)
